text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MAY 4,

IRM 4.23.4.3(8). Changed GMCM to 60 days after the case is updated to Status 12 or 30 days after the initial appointment, whichever is ﬁrst. Per IGM SBSE-01-1019-0042, Group Manager Concurrence Meeting (GMCM).
IRM 4.23.4.5. Revised to state that there are two types of large case audits; LB&I exams using a team approach and LB&I stand-alone ET audits.
IRM 4.23.4.5.1. (2) Added Note that Form 13744-I is not suitable for ET Specialists. (3) Deleted instructions for Form 4764-IC.
IRM 4.23.4.5.2. Pre-exam procedures revised for both ET specialists working LB&I cases and ET Examiners working stand-alone cases.
IRM 4.23.4.5.3. Mid-cycle risk analysis procedure revised to apply to all cases with an Estimated Closing Date (ECD) exceeding 12 months.
IRM 4.23.4.5.4. Approval for additional time delegated to the SB/SE ET team group manager.
IRM 4.23.4.5.5. Revised instructions provided for preparation and distribution of IDRs.
IRM 4.23.4.5.6. “ET team manager” replaced with “ET group manager”.
Editorial and technical changes have been made throughout this section. Links and cross-references
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
AUDIENCE

This section contains instructions and guidelines for all Large Business & International (LB&I), Tax Exempt/Governmental Entities (TE/GE), and Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) employees dealing with employment tax issues.
Mandatory Items - IMS General Case Requirements
Tax - General Procedures and Workpapers

) Purpose: This section: • Describes various employment tax initiatives, • Details general procedures for employment tax returns selected for amination, and • Covers workpapers generally used in employment tax examinations. Note: Other functions and operating divisions may have additional or procedures. (

) Audience: This section contains instructions and guidelines for all Large Business & International (LB&I), Tax Exempt/Government Entities (TE/GE), and Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) employees dealing with ment tax issues. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Specialty Examination Policy of the Small Self-Employed Division. (
) Program Owner: Program Manager - Employment Tax Policy. The mission Employment Tax Policy is to establish effective policies and procedures, to support compliance with employment tax laws. (

) Primary Stakeholders: • Employment Tax - Workload Selection and Delivery (SE:S- :DCE:HQ:ECS:S:ETEGCS:EWSD) • Specialty Examination - Employment Tax (SE:S:DCE:E:SE:ET) • Specialty Examination Policy, Employment Tax Policy P:ETP) • Federal, State and Local Governments / Employment Tax Area, Organizations - Examination (FSL/ET) • Other areas that are affected by these policies and procedures Appeals, Counsel, SB/SE Examination, LB&I, and TE/GE. (
) Program Scope: The mission of Employment Tax Policy is to establish effective policies and procedures, and to support compliance with tax laws. (

) This IRM outlines an examiner’s responsibilities regarding employment tax workpapers and will assist the examiner in meeting quality standards and ensuring appropriate and consistent audit procedures. (
) Employment tax provisions are found at Internal Revenue Code Subtitle C: • Chapter
, Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA), • Chapter
, Railroad Retirement Tax Act (RRTA), • Chapter
, Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA), • Chapter
, Federal Income Tax Withholding (FITW), and • Chapter
, General Provisions relating to employment taxes and lection of income taxes at source. (
) The Employment Tax Program is governed by Policy Statements and other internal guidance that apply to all Service personnel regardless of operating division. The Policy Statements found in IRM
, Servicewide Policies Authorities, Servicewide Policy Statements, apply to all employment tax Internal Revenue Manual

The Employment Tax Program is governed by Policy Statements and other internal guidance that apply to all Service personnel regardless of operating division. The Policy Statements found in IRM 1.2.1, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Servicewide Policy Statements, apply to all employment tax
) IRM
provides Servicewide instructions for all operating divisions with employees involved with the correct ﬁling, reporting, and payment of employ- ment taxes. IRM

serves as the foundation for consistent administration of employment taxes by various IRS operating divisions. By providing one source of authority for all operating divisions, the Service greatly reduces philosophical and procedural inconsistencies.
The following table lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions:

: IRM sections, the majority of which are owned by SB/SE Specialty Examination Policy, provide Servicewide instructions for em- ployees of all operating divisions involved with the correct ﬁling, ing, and payment of employment taxes. IRM

) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accord with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR. See IRC
). For additional information about TBOR, see https://www.irs.gov/ taxpayer-bill-of-rights. (

) The Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS whose employees assist taxpayers experiencing economic harm, are seeking help in resolving tax problems that have not been resolved through normal procedures, or who believe that an IRS system or procedure not working as it should. Pub

, Taxpayer Advocate Service - We Are to Help You, provides contact and additional information. The program is designed to alleviate taxpayer hardships that arise from systemic problems the application of the Internal Revenue Code. In addition, see IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria, and IRM
, TAS tions Assistance Request (OAR) Process, for additional information. (

) Employment tax examiners should consider the disclosure provisions when preparing agreed and unagreed case reports. See the Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure web site at: Home.aspx for additional information. (
) Unless instructed otherwise, examiners will use the ETLS - Employment Tax Lead Sheets described in IRM
, Guide for Examiners Using ETLS - Employment Tax Lead Sheets, developed speciﬁcally for employment tax cases. Note: ET case ﬁles must contain the ETLS mandatory leadsheets or the RGS

) SB/SE examiners working on large case audits generally will follow preparation, speciﬁc audit techniques, and case closing procedures unique these type of audits. See IRM
, Procedures for Employment Tax Examiners Working on Large Case Audits - General. (
) The Issue Management System (IMS) is required to be used during ment tax examinations by examiners assigned to Specialty – Employment Operations. See IRM
, Guide for Examiners Using Issue System (IMS) and subsequent subsections. (

) The examination workpapers and reports provide the basis for the reached by the examiner. Only on the basis of the material in the can a reviewer determine if the examination was complete and correct. workpapers must provide explanations, analyses, and conclusions reached should be sufficiently complete so, generally, no additional comments are needed in a transmittal letter. (

) Workpapers must clearly and concisely state the issue, facts, audit steps, taxpayer’s position, and conclusion for each issue examined. In addition, papers must document if the following actions and/or audit steps were • Interviews of appropriate parties were conducted, • All required employment tax and information returns were accurately and timely ﬁled, • The examiner reconciled Form(s) W-
to payroll, and • All required Form(s)
were correctly ﬁled (e.g., no worker cation issue exists or backup withholding is not warranted). Note: The examiner will document the reason for not addressing any of the actions. (
) IRM
, Examination of Returns, Workpaper System and Case File Assembly, also provides further guidance on workpaper preparation. (

) Workpapers are key in the support of all IRS positions taken when making justments. Properly prepared workpapers: of Workpapers a. Support the IRS position for any appealed or litigated issue, b. Document action(s) taken, c. Form the basis of necessary reports, d. Facilitate managerial, technical, or other review, e. Facilitate authorized review by other governmental agencies, and f. Provide subsequent examiners a clear audit trail and scope of the examination. (

) Workpapers are required in every examination case. Workpapers should include all evidence gathered by the examiner to show the work performed, audit techniques followed, tax law relied on, and conclusions reached. ing workpapers must be prepared when necessary to fully document all and conclusions. These supporting workpapers must be attached to the priate lead sheet. (

) As workpapers are used in the preparation of the audit report, examiners ensure that the information contained in the workpapers is consistent with fully supports the ﬁnal conclusions reached. The workpapers will be relied upon to support the issues in appealed or litigated cases. The workpapers

) IRM
, Examination of Returns, Workpaper System and Case File Assembly, also provides further guidance on workpaper preparation. (

) Workpapers are key in the support of all IRS positions taken when making justments. Properly prepared workpapers: a. Support the IRS position for any appealed or litigated issue, b. Document action(s) taken, c. Form the basis of necessary reports, d. Facilitate managerial, technical, or other review, e. Facilitate authorized review by other governmental agencies, and f. Provide subsequent examiners a clear audit trail and scope of the prior examination. (

) Workpapers are required in every examination case. Workpapers should include all evidence gathered by the examiner to show the work performed, audit techniques followed, tax law relied on, and conclusions reached. ing workpapers must be prepared when necessary to fully document all and conclusions. These supporting workpapers must be attached to the priate lead sheet. (

) As workpapers are used in the preparation of the audit report, examiners ensure that the information contained in the workpapers is consistent with fully supports the ﬁnal conclusions reached. The workpapers will be relied upon to support the issues in appealed or litigated cases. The workpapers Internal Revenue Manual
Employment be provided to a subsequent reviewer or the taxpayer when requested under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) process. (

) Use of the Employment Tax Lead Sheets (ETLS) will help the examiner all workpaper requirements. Use of stand-alone workpapers, while not ited, does not relieve the examiner from meeting workpaper requirements. (

) Properly prepared workpapers must provide adequate documentation to support conclusions. Without sufficient documentation, it is not possible for reviewers to verify that the scope of the examination is appropriate, or the basis of an adjustment is accurate. Examiners should always cite legal authority to support the conclusions (e.g., Internal Revenue Code, applicable regulations, court cases, revenue rulings and/or revenue procedures). (

) Workpapers must be neat, legible, clear, and concise. The legibility of exami- nation workpapers and reports is an important aspect of the overall quality of the examination. The easier it is to read workpapers and reports, the easier is to understand them. (

) Workpapers must be clearly headed: • Taxpayer name, • Taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN), • Tax period examined, • Date workpapers were prepared, • Name or initials of the examiner, and • Issues or items being examined. (

) Workpapers must be indexed, numbered, and securely fastened together. Index workpapers as they are prepared. If an issue cannot be fully explained on the speciﬁc lead sheet, supporting workpapers must be prepared, and attached behind the appropriate lead sheet. Supporting workpapers may be required to provide detailed explanations, analysis, schedules, and/or putations. For example, supporting workpapers would be used to schedule wage adjustments applicable to each employee. (

) The volume of supporting workpapers prepared during examinations will vary depending on the size of the entity and the number and type of issues developed. While there is no ﬁxed requirement to include speciﬁc schedules analyses in the supporting workpapers, examiners must include enough mation to support the conclusion documented on the lead sheet. Any notes taken during interviews conducted must be included in the case ﬁle as support of the ﬁnal case resolution. (

) Workpapers should reﬂect what was actually accomplished during the nation. The workpapers should not include superﬂuous documentation, of irrelevant data, or the examiner’s personal opinions relating to the or the business. For example, copies of CPA workpapers or reports should be included in the workpapers where they do not contribute to the develop- ment of an issue. In addition, examiners should never make personal comments about a taxpayer. Remember, taxpayers always have the right to request any and all workpapers included in the case ﬁle under the Freedom Information Act (FOIA). (
) The case ﬁle should include a well-documented, contemporaneous case history sheet. For SB/SE examiners using IMS, the Examining Office’s Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

The case ﬁle should include a well-documented, contemporaneous case history sheet. For SB/SE examiners using IMS, the Examining Office’s

Record in IMS should be used for this purpose. For non-IMS users, Form 9984, Examining Officer’s Activity Record, is used for this purpose and is numbered as Workpaper 100. The case history documents:
numbered as Workpaper

The case history documents: • A summary of contacts made during the examination, • All actions taken by the examiner, taxpayers and/or reviewers (e.g., manager), • Time spent on the case, and • All discussions held with the manager and decisions reached. In addition, the case history will document: • The date and method for delivery of publications: Example:
: Mailed Pub
, Your Rights as a Taxpayer, and Notice
, Privacy Act Notice, to taxpayer with the initial contact letter. • Other publications should be noted if applicable: Example: Pub
, Do You Qualify for Relief Under Section
?, Pub
, Fast Track Settlement - A Process for Prompt Resolution of Small Business Self Employed Tax Issues, and/or Pub

, Fast Track Settlement Brochure, for case examinations. • Any extended period of inactivity, such as leave or extended details. all SB/SE examiners, a comment is required if there is no activity on case for a period of
days. The comment should fully explain the reasons for inactivity. Note: See IRM
, Scheduling the Appointment, and IRM
, Contact with Taxpayers, for additional requirements. (
) If the case was initiated by a referral, examiners must include a printed copy the “Specialist Referral System (SRS) Referral Form” in the workpapers. (

) Examiners have different workpapers available depending on the type of ex- amination being worked and the type of training received: a. Examiners working non-large case employment tax examinations will the ETLS. See IRM
, Guide for Examiners Using ETLS - ment Tax Lead Sheets, for speciﬁc information. b. Examiners working large case employment tax examinations will use workpapers discussed in IRM
, Procedures for Employment Examiners Working on Large Case Audits - General, and its (

) Risk-based decision-making is critical to the effective allocation of limited ex- amination resources. Workpaper #

, Risk Analysis Workpaper, is not required for each new issue added or for each issue declassiﬁed - it is only required for each taxpayer/entity. This design supports the Value-Added Decision Making (
) concept and the Mid-Audit Decision Point (

% concept of the ETLS process. Note: The Risk Analysis Workpaper is not required for ET TCOs. When an ET expands the scope beyond the classiﬁed issue or limits the scope, the is discussed with the manager and the decision is documented on Form

Employment (

) All examiners trained in the use of the Issue Management System (IMS) are required to use IMS for all case management, regardless of the type of for Examiners being worked. Use of IMS is required for all employment tax audits by Issue ment tax examiners. IMS is designed to: System • Support remotely located examiners, • Enhance issue identiﬁcation, • Improve issue tracking and reporting, • Share information through a centralized data repository, and • Capture data in support of performance measures. (

) Examiners will establish their cases in the IMS program. When required, the IMS system can be used to: • Perform preliminary risk analysis, • Perform in-process risk analysis for issues, • Set-up and monitor case assignments, • Input and monitor issue progress and status of IDRs, • Prepare and monitor Forms

, • Input case documents and time information for each issue, • Generate various time reports and activity records, and • Create a next case cycle automatically populating selected from a previous case cycle. (
) For more information on IMS, refer to the IMS web site at: https://irssource. web.irs.gov/LBI/Sit

) To ensure consistency, all examiners will prepare and complete Information Document Requests (IDRs) within IMS, including annotating the Form

, Information Document Request, as appropriate (e.g., Date IDR Issued, Date Information due by). All Examiners will update the IDR status and date ﬁelds via IDR Edit Status screen. The IDR status choices will vary depending on the current status of the IDR (e.g., Issued, Received, Revoked, Closed, etc.).

Note: Updating an IDR status as “Received” will not stop the days outstanding from running. After reviewing an IDR response for completeness, the IDR status should be updated to “Closed” to prevent erroneous outstanding appearing in IDR statistics and managerial reports.

th quarter return) for each tax year that the issue is examined. The time spent on the case will be charged to the examined ET issue(s) reﬂected on the key return(s), as appropriate. of how to set up a case, its issues, and how to charge time are provided in supplemental training materials. (

) Tax Compliance Officers (TCO) and Tax Examiners (TE) will set up the issue on each return included in the examination. If other issues are found, they will be added to the key return(s) (generally, the

) Tax and Penalty Data Fields: The examiner will: a. Complete the appropriate tax and penalty data ﬁelds under Entities/ ERCS Closing Data TAB on the Edit Entity screen for every in the IMS case; the case will not close in IMS until this closing data is entered for each return. b. Reference the proprietary Employment Tax Examination Report program and Form

, Examination Closing Record, for the tax and penalty amounts to enter in these data ﬁelds. c. Enter the claim amounts, deﬁciency amounts, or over-assessments. If data ﬁeld is not applicable to the return, enter zero in the ﬁeld. d. Examiner will complete the “IRC section”, “Penalty”, and “Penalty Abatement” data ﬁelds. Zeros are not required in these data ﬁelds if are not relevant or applicable to the return. Note: The information entered on the Entity Closing Data screen is marized on the Team Web Site (TWS) under Case Entities and Entity Closing Data screen. (

) Wage Adjustment Data Fields: The examiner will: a. Complete the wage adjustment data ﬁelds under each Issue on the justment Amt/Source” screen. No entries are made for any Standard Audit Index Number (SAIN)

“Proposed Adjustment per Examiner Amount” ﬁeld for the appropriate year’s return. The examiner’s work papers will be the reference for the amounts entered in this ﬁeld. -X, Adjusted Employer’s QUARTERLY Federal Tax Return or Claim for Refund, or similar form will be the reference material for amounts in this ﬁeld. e. The “Sum of
Adjustments” entry applies to ET large case tions. (

) Examiners will close their cases in IMS to correspond with closure of the case ﬁle to their manager. ET Managers can then perform their reviews and indicate concurrence with the closure of cases from the group using the “Manager Concurrence” feature on the Team We

ite (TWS) and selecting “yes”. These timely steps allow other stakeholders (e.g., Appeals, Technical Services, and Centralized Case Processing) to access cases electronically in IMS/TWS. IMS case closing procedures and processes are described in detail in ET IMS course books, job aids, and check sheets. Additional closing procedures in IMS involving stakeholders will be provided when they are fully operational for employment tax cases. (

) For employment tax purposes, there are two types of large case audits:
LB&I exams using a team approach (ET and LB&I Income Tax are for involved in the audit), and Tax
LB&I stand-alone ET audits (Only ET is involved in the audit). Working on Audits: (

) All examiners working on LB&I team examinations must follow LB&I team procedures. Examiners working LB&I stand-alone employment tax audits use either the procedures discussed below or the “ETLS - Employment Lead Sheets”, covered in IRM

The sections included in IRM will provide guidance speciﬁc to LB&I team audit procedures, including: • Mandatory workpapers, • Pre-examination analysis and audit plan requirements, • Risk analysis, • Requests for additional time, • Information Document Request (IDR) preparation, • Form
, Notice of Proposed Adjustment preparation, • Issue Lead Sheet, • Workpaper organization, • Package Audit, and • Workpaper disposition. (
) Examiners must prepare an individual Form
, Information Document Request (IDR), for each issue being developed, and a Form
, Notice Workpapers Proposed Adjustment (NOPA), for each issue adjusted. (
) The examiner will create Form
, Risk Analysis Worksheet. Note: The use of Form
-I, Issue Based Risk Analysis and Examination described in IRM
, Issue-Based Examination Plan, is not for ET Specialists. (
) The examiner will create an audit plan for large case examinations of examination workpaper cover sheets: • Form
-A, LB&I Examination Plan, Part III - Summary of Assign- ments,(Optional for LB&I IC cases per IRM
, IC Plan) and • Form

-B, LB&I Examination Plan, Part III - Examination Section. These forms are used for employment tax pre-examination planning and the lead sheets to the audit workpapers and audit results. Note: The most current versions of Forms
-A and
-B can be obtained the Forms Repository at http://publish.no.irs.gov/catlg.html. (
) For further guidance, examiners should refer to IRM
, Workpaper System and Case File Assembly, and IRM
, LB&I Examination

) During the pre-examination analysis phase, the employment tax specialist should analyze available information, including: Pre-Exam Information Analysis IDRS research to obtain information to determine ﬁling compliance and identify potential employment tax issues, including but not limited to: AMDIS, BMFOL / IMFOL, CFINK, INOLE, IRPTR, PMFOL, IRPTR, BRTVU. Review and consideration of related tax and information returns. Veri- ﬁcation that all required returns were ﬁled can be completed by securing the IDRS command code BMFOL. The examiner should review a copy of the income tax return ﬁled by the taxpayer to determine if there are any large, unusual or question- able (LUQ) employment tax issues. The EUP, “Employee User Portal”, provides a scanned copy of the ﬁled return that can be inspected for potential employment tax issues, including but not limited to: First four pages of Form
, U.S. Corporation Income Tax Return Form
, “Affiliations Schedule”, Consolidated schedule of income and deductions “Statement of Other Deductions”, Schedule M-
, “Reconciliation of Income (Loss) per Books With Income per Return”

Pre-Exam Information Analysis Internet research, including but not limited to: Company website, Security and Exchange, Commission (SEC) ﬁlings, Westlaw, Lexis, Accurint, and news articles and other company information. The examiner should review taxpayer historical ﬁles as well as any prior employment tax audit reports for potential issues. ) Risk-based decision-making is critical to the effective allocation of limited ex- amination resources. A risk assessment must be conducted: • With the initial planning of the examination, • When
percent of the case time has been reached, and • When a signiﬁcant event occurs. (
) The ﬁrst risk analysis described in (

) above is prepared during the initial planning phase of the examination. Depending on materiality and/or compli- ance considerations, the risk analysis can be done on an issue-by-issue or a case basis. • Form
, Risk Analysis Worksheet, should be completed as part of the pre-audit analysis • Employment Tax group manager must approve all risk analyses (
) A mid-cycle risk analysis is required on all large case ET examinations with Estimated Closing Date (ECD) exceeding
months and must be approved

) and (
) of IRM

) The mid-cycle risk analysis includes time applied and indicates if time is needed. The examiner should also state the potential tax liability issue and by year, and provide a brief assessment of the audit. (

) After the agent completes the mid-cycle risk analysis, it may be apparent additional time is needed to complete the examination. ) Prior to issuing an IDR, the examiner should discuss with the taxpayer team coordinator the speciﬁc information that is needed. The taxpayer able to explain what type of information is available and may suggest a preferred wording for the IDR. Conferring with the team coordinator also ensures that the examiner does not ask for already available information. (
) The team coordinator may determine the numbering system used for all issued. An IDR log is maintained to provide a source for assigning and to monitor response times. (

) Three copies of each IDR request should be prepared and distributed as follows; a. The original will be given to the taxpayer, b. A copy of the IDR (paper or electronic) will be given to the team nator, and c. A copy of the IDR (paper or electronic) will be maintained by the ment Tax Specialist with the issue workpapers. IMS can be used for purpose.
The original will be given to the taxpayer, A copy of the IDR (paper or electronic) will be given to the team coordi
nator, and A copy of the IDR (paper or electronic) will be maintained by the ment Tax Specialist with the issue workpapers. IMS can be used for this purpose.
Note: Refer to IRM 4.46.4.6.1, General IDR Procedures.
) IDRs should generally include only one issue or subject. This results in a faster turnaround time since information covering multiple topics may need to come from several sources. (
) The IDR Management Process is used for all cases. Examiners should follow both the general IDR procedures and enforcement IDR procedures found in IRM Exhibit
, Requirements for Issuing IDRs, and Exhibit
, IDR Enforcement Process. (

, IDR Enforcement Process, will be followed by the SB/SE examiner working with the LB&I income tax team. (
) The mandatory Enforcement Process has three graduated steps:
Delinquency Notice (Letter
, Delinquency Notice)
Pre-Summons Letter (Letter
, Pre Summons)

Summons Note: If an examiner issues a Pre-Summons Letter or Summons under this process, the examiner must contact their local Tax Exempt/Government Entity (TEGE) Counsel for support, not LB&I Counsel. TEGE Counsel will contact LB&I Counsel for assistance and coordination as needed. If LB&I Counsel personnel are assigned to the case, the examiner must still use local TEGE Counsel. (

) The process does not preclude the examination team from using judgment a case-by-case basis. Continuous collaboration is needed to reach realistic dates and dates can be revised based upon the facts and circumstances. A detailed description of the IDR Management Process can be found at IRM
, Information Document Request Process and IRM Exhibit
, Requirements for Issuing IDRs. The IDR Enforcement Process procedures be found at IRM Exhibit
, IDR Enforcement Process. (
) If the taxpayer does not agree with the examiner’s determination and the is likely to be appealed, prepare a Form
-A containing the facts and the taxpayer’s written acknowledgment of the facts (AOF). Refer to IRM
, Issue the Draft Form

-A with a Pro-Forma AOF IDR. ET cialists on team audits with the LB&I income tax team will generally use the AOF; ET Specialists working stand-alone employment tax audits can follow AOF at their discretion. (
) All adjustments are proposed on a Form
, Notice of Proposed as they are developed. This form serves as a cover sheet to Form
-A, of planation of Adjustments, which is attached to fully explain the basis for proposing each adjustment. (
) Potential adjustments should be discussed with the team coordinator and taxpayer prior to issuing the notice. (
) The ET group manager reviews and signs the Form(s)

This signature indicates the group manager has accepted the examiner’s position on the issue. A Territory Manager’s approval/signature is required on all Form(s) involving issues on: • LB&I exams using a team approach or stand-alone ET audits for Industry Cases (IC) with adjustments of $
million or more, and • LB&I exams using a team approach or stand-alone ET audits for Large Corporate Compliance (LCC) cases with adjustments of $
million or more. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

page (
) The Form(s)
and Form(s)
-A are attached to the ﬁnal audit report. (
) Form

-B, LB&I Examination Plan, Part III - Examination Procedures Section, is the lead sheet describing the audit procedures applied and the Sheets clusions reached for each issue and should: • Be properly headed, • Include a discussion of the applicable law, • Document the audit trail, and • Lead to a clear and logical conclusion. (
) Supporting documentation should be attached as a workpaper when further explanation is needed to support the conclusions reached. (
) Lead sheets also serve as an index for any workpapers that relate to a issue. All workpapers should be numbered, indexed, and referenced to the issue lead sheet. (

) All workpapers, either paper or electronic, should be associated with the ap- propriate issue SAIN number and issue name. This will ensure all team Organization members’ audit case ﬁles are organized in a consistent manner, allowing for ease of review by the team coordinator, group managers, and others. (

) SAIN codes for SB/SE examiners can be found by referring to the current SAIN Job Aid for ET, available on the “Employment Tax Knowledge Base” at “Employment Tax Resources/Tools”: employmenttaxtools/landingview.aspx. (

) In support of the LB&I Executive Compensation Strategy, ET specialists are required to verify up-to-date ﬁling of officers’ and key executives’ returns Executive IDRS command code IMFOLI when conducting an LB&I stand-alone ment tax examination. The examiner should use their judgement to if key officer and executive returns should be further inspected. If issues are found, Form
, Examination Information Report, will be completed and forwarded per local procedures. Additional guidance on inspection of returns is found in Exhibit
, Inspection of Key Officer and Executive Returns. Also see “Corporate Executive Compliance” at: http://www.irs.gov/ Businesses/Corporations/Corporate-Executive-Compliance. (

) The employment tax audit workpapers provide important historical and are valuable for any subsequent cycles that may be opened. Disposition a. For Large Corporate Compliance (LCC) cases, electronic employment audit workpapers and related forms (i.e. copy of audit reports and ments, Form
-Examination Plan Series work papers, Form
, relevant workpapers, Risk Analysis, NOPAs, etc.) must be uploaded to IMS or backed up to a virtual server, if available. See IRM

, Other IMS Issues, File Size, File Limitations and Encryption Policy, for information. Note: Large Corporate Compliance (LCC) program replaces the nated Industry Case (CIC) program and covers compliance oversight for LB&Is largest corporate taxpayers. (

) When closing a related case at the same time as the primary/key case ﬁle, required administrative workpapers do not need to be duplicated in the related case ﬁles if: • The related cases are being closed from the group at the same time, and • The returns are properly linked on the Examination Returns Control System (ERCS) and identiﬁed as being either the Primary/Key Return the Related Return.
